boardgame.name: Makahit
boardgame.description:
There are many handmade components with the game, but also many professional produced, such as the game board or the play money.

Each player moves his token around the board, to his choice by the throw on one die or two dice.
There are switches where to decide which way to follow.
Moving along players discover stars and songs and combine them to make a hit ("MAKAHIT").
With these they challenge for a place in the top ten in order to make money.
The money enables a player to buy gold discs, and the first to buy 5 gold discs is the winner of the game.

In the time intended to be released, the game could have been a hit. But as the author mentions in the professional produced rules: "Owing to legal difficulties it is not possible to print the actual names of stars and songs on the cards."

boardgame.name: Ostroleka 1831
boardgame.description:
A game about the battle of Ostroleka (May 26th, 1831) which was the turning point of the Russo-Polish War (November Uprising).

Also included are the counters and scenarios dealing with the Napoleonic battle of Ostroleka (February 15th-16th, 1807) between the French and the Russians.

The game is the herald of the new "Napoleonic" system designed for Taktyka i Strategia's games, dealing with medium and large battles of the Napoleonic Wars and the Russo-Polish War of 1831. Counters represent entire regiments, one hex represents 250m, one turn represents 30 minutes.

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

boardgame.name: Mafioso
boardgame.description:
This game is the predecessor of the well known game The Mob/Capone.

It was first time presented 1987 at the legendary "death row" of the London Toys and Games Fair.

Game components are of a very high standard regarding there were only few copies released: 4 x 8 large wooden and brightly colored discs, each depicting another different family member and -car with a colored sticker fixed to it,32 wooden hood pieces (German "Poeppel"), 56 colored racket cards, 40 gold bars (bankroll chips), a lot of play money and a large, colorful gameboard with comic-like drawings.

Added is a Mafia book containing the stories of real family members in the year of 1931, fixed with the some drawings you find on the member discs.

Game-play is nearly the same as in The Mob: Many cards for only some places to conquer, but nobody knows how much are at the same time in play!
Possibilities to invest in legal businesses or to send an opponent to the fishes (cement boots are replaced by an offer from the Colt Company which you can't refuse...)are also presented.

Players are on the run for the gold bars and to be the first to amass 10 of them!

boardgame.name: Secret Agent: The Card Game With the Magic Monocle
boardgame.description:
The Pepys card game with the legendary magic monocle.

Game consists of 39 cards; 4 master agents, 5 secret agents, 5 secret plans, 5 inns, 5 trains, 5 planes, 5 cars and 5 M.T.B cards (and the monocle, of course...).

Object of the game is collect six cards:1 secret agent, 1 secret plan, an inn and 3 of the same kind of transport.
This is done by pick-up-and-discard.
In order to win none of these cards may have a secret message written on it.

If a player has collected the complete set he can call for help of the Master Agent (MA), thus using the magic monocle to reveal if any of his cards has a secret message written on it: He spreads them out and checks the colour coded strips at the base of his cards.

If there is none, he wins, if there is - play commences, now knowing which cards to discard.

As with nearly all Pepys games outstanding graphic design, the Monocle a really nice gimmick.

boardgame.name: Planes Game
boardgame.description:
Trick-taking card game of the Pepys Series Card Games, as usual well produced and designed.

Game consists of 44 cards: 12 class cards, 2 helicopter cards and 30 trio cards(depicting various planes in different classes and point value).

Object of the game is to win cards with tricks.
After dealing out the hand further cards are turned up until a class card appears. Players then choose 3 cards from their hands which they believe give a good point value vs. the class.
The packs are revealed simultaneously, winner of the trick is the one with the most point value (helicopters belonging to every class).
The winner also takes all the cards exposed by the other players depicting the class.
When the last class card has been played for the game ends and all the tricks are valued with a special count score.

Gameplay is the same as in the CAR GAME and GIRL from the same publisher.

boardgame.name: Pandas' Party
boardgame.description:
Unusual game from the Pepys Card Game Series.

It consists of 54 playing cards and two key cards.

The 54 cards can be laid out to complete a large puzzle picture containing 9 x 6 cards.

All cards are dealt out, the player with the letter card "F" begins play by laying out this card. Next player in line tries to add a fitting card to it and so on.

Winner is the player getting rid of all his cards first.
Other players receive penalty points for cards left in their hands.
After reaching a points limit agreed beforehand play ends.

You can see the wartime production by the grey and thick card quality and the not-so-glossy-graphics, but still top !

boardgame.name: 4th Corner
boardgame.description:
As the maze expands, can you be the first to reach the exit? Players start in the middle of a maze. Every turn a player picks a tile and connects it with the tiles already on the table and then moves his/her pawn if desired or possible. Players attempt to keep their paths open and to block or trap their opponents with strategic placement of the wall tiles. After the fourth exterior corner tile has been placed, tiles may be replaced as well as placed, and the exit tile is shuffled into the draw pile. The first player to the exit tile when it appears scores zero points. Every other player gets points depending on how far their pawn is when the exit is reached by anyone. The fewest points after a number of rounds is the winner.

The only board game to receive the Top Toy 2008 award from Toy Directory Monthly! (See link below)

Note: If playing with only two players, try giving each player two pawns to move.

Received award for Best Vacation Toys 2009 from Dr. Toy.

boardgame.name: Liebe & Intrige
boardgame.description:
Each player represents a family trying to marry their three daughters. The daughters have three characteristics: Reputation, beauty, and education, all of which may increase and decrease in value during the course of the game. There are 14 gentlemen in the game, each of them demanding a minimum value in each characteristic. A daughter gets married immediately when she has collected three cards of the same gentleman, and meets the gentleman's standards in each of the three characteristics.

The game ends when a family marries all of their daughters. Points are scored from husbands, action cards, and also from majorities in each characteristic.

The game board depicts different parts of a town, each of them with a different number of available gentlemen cards.

A player's turn consists of:
1. Moving to a different region of the town.
2. Doing a region-specific action, or trying to scheme against another daughter in the same region.
3. Drawing an action card.

Region-specific actions usually mean choosing a gentleman card from those available, but sometimes also cause changes in a daughter's characteristics. Scheming against another daughter means trying to steal a gentleman card from them, by rolling a die. Action cards can be played anytime during a player's turn, and sometimes also as a reaction to cards played by other players.

boardgame.name: Grzybobranie
Grzybobranie w zaczarowanym lesie
Grzybobranie w Zielonym Gaju
Grzybobranie, Cudowna Podróż
Mushrooms
Na grzyby
boardgame.description:
Grzybobranie - "The Mushrooming" - is a very old children roll and move game (it was old in early 1970-s...).

Players roll a single die and move their mug-shaped pawns along the road. When they stop on a space with one or more uncollected mushrooms (wooden or plastic pieces usually) they put them into their mugs. Red mushrooms are "bad", other ones are "good". Some spaces are event ones - like gain/lose a turn, go forward or backward, discard one or more mushrooms etc. When all the players reach the end of the track the one with most "good" mushrooms wins.

The game is very popular in Poland - there are many versions by many publishers (they often differ in the shape of the path, the number of mushrooms to collect, and the adventures included).

boardgame.name: The Game of Ship's Cargo
boardgame.description:
This is an interesting 19th Century card game in which players take turns offering one of their goods for auction. The other players then secretly bid for the card, with all bids revealed simultaneously. The winner pays for the card, and then starts the next auction. Each player starts with 12 bidding tokens, and the goal is to collect two sets of cards. If, by the end of the game, no player has collected two sets, the player who is closest wins.

F.G. & Co. published a reprint of the game in 2004 with the subtitle A Nineteenth Century Game of Commerce.

boardgame.name: Fortuna
boardgame.description:
This game is a variation on the Monopoly theme, with a few differences:

- There are 44 spaces on the board (not 40 as in Monopoly).

- Instead of throwing dice players use sets of 12 tokens with numbers ranged 1-12 and move accordingly to the number shown on the chosen token. Thus Fortuna is much less random than Monopoly.

- There are four "restaurants" and three "railway stations" spaces instead of 4 railway stations in original Monopoly.

- In addition to a possibility of being sent to hospital (an equivalent of prison) players have an option to go to vacation.

Other rules are very similar to the rules of Monopoly.

The board represents Warsaw in 1901.

boardgame.name: Rebels & Royalist
boardgame.description:
Rebels & Royalist is a multi-player wargame taking place in an imaginary country. Each player controls a faction of rebels and is trying to get their faction to control five (of twelve) cities or three Royalist cities. Players receive production for their holdings, build units, move and fight, etc., in a reasonably familiar fashion. There are rules for supply and fairly elaborate rules for scouting.

There are two unusual features of the game. One is that the Royalists take part in the game but are not controlled by a single player - when it is the Royalist's turn to build or move the player to the left of the last player to do something takes control of them. The other is that every turn has an alliance phase, in which the players may make or break alliances between their factions. The player order for each turn is determined by drawing cards, and all factions in an alliance move when one of the faction cards is drawn (the members may vote to wait for a later card rather than moving at the first opportunity).

boardgame.name: Red Square
boardgame.description:
Red Square is a very rare Monopoly-style board game with a Soviet theme that was marketed in 1990 (with a copyright of 1988).

Unlike Monopoly, Red Square players compete for privileges -- not properties -- to move up the Soviet social ladder through their status in the Soviet Military and Communist Party. Players acquire wealth by buying and selling on the black market and correctly answering trivia questions about Soviet society and other Russian curiosities.

The winner is the first person to weave their way through the three social classes and make it to Red Square. Players exchange their privileges to move to the next social level -- a concept that is known as nomenklatura in Russian.

boardgame.name: StreetSmart
boardgame.description:
StreetSmart models a rapidly growing city in a developing country.

The players are Capitalists/Politicians/Maffiabosses trying to control as many neighborhoods/slums as possible. Each turn you move one of the city's characters: the Consumer, the Gangster, the Policeman, the Smoker or the Fireman. The characters are moved by simultaneously playing direction cards. Predicting your opponents' moves in order to disrupt their plans is a major part of the game. The game is fast and easy; for a more complex gameplay, there are expansions included in the game:

The Bureaucrat Game adds the Bureaucrat character who creates Addresses and grants Land Titles. The Cholera Game adds an epidemic as well as the Garbageman, Bacterium and Doctor characters. In the Power & Water Game you fight for access to electricity and freshwater for your subjects.

Each expansion can be played in Original Mode, in Chess Mode (no luck factor) or in Political Mode (The players elect a Mayor who then decides who controls which character.)

boardgame.name: The Club
The Club
boardgame.description:
The Club is a slightly satirical game about life in the fast lane - a board game about love and about people's need to meet one another.

The whole game takes place in a nightclub and the game board is the dance floor. On their turn players push three new dancers to the dance floor from their own bar counter (edge of the game board) and as they come into play they push others towards the center of the dance floor. Once two dancers meet in the heat of the night they can be made into couples and the better the match the more players score. If only two of the four visible qualities match then the dancers have a one-night-stand which is not a very long term fun and is thus worth only one point. With three matching qualities the dancers actually like one another, start dating and that is worth four points. If all the four visible qualities match then the dancers get the "happily ever after" the one true love we all search for and thus it is worth full 5 points.

Each dancer also has a secret quality that can and will alter the basic score. For example if a guy has a large... "personality" then the player gets two extra points unless the other dancer is drunk, because if she is she wouldn't notice the difference. Girl's beautiful roommate on the other hand only has a function in the one-night-stands and the fun the couple would have means now triple fun and thus the player gets triple points. There are 12 different secret qualities in the game ranging from heart-broken to those who still live with their mom.

Occasionally the game gets spiced up by one of the three special charachters in the game. Bouncer can remove any of the dancer from the game board where as a Rock Star walks into the game normally, but once (s)he has gathered a fan crowd and he's completely surrounded player can take the Rock Star and four adjacent dancers back to his hotel room and form two couples out of them. The bully is the guy who harasses women and picks a fight with men and once he enters the game his mere presence prevents any dancer next to him to be part of a couple.

In the end the player who has been the best cupido wins the game. In other words the best scorer wins.

boardgame.name: Biznes po polsku
boardgame.description:
Biznes po polsku - "Business in Polish" (not "in Poland!") - is a Monopoly based game.

The action takes place in Poland in 1990-s. Socialism is over, capitalism begins. Players try to run their small businesses - hot-dog kiosks, second-hands, money exchange offices, fitness clubs, gasoline stations, etc. There is a lot of jokes and puns connected with the economic system transformation and the politics of the 90-s in this game, particularly on its event cards. The game money notes are well-done one sided copies of present Polish banknotes.

The game mechanics is almost exactly the same as it is in Monopoly, but there are a few noticeable differences. The most important one is that the spaces forming a set are not necessarily close to each other - they can be even placed on opposite sides of a board. The board is not a square but a 11x9 rectangle.

boardgame.name: Channel X
boardgame.description:
The last entry from the Pepys company in the line of the "Double Feature Games".

Game consists of 52 playing cards, 6 little channel and 6 little advertising company cards. Furthermore there is 300.000 GBP in "Pepys Currency".

Object of the game is to make money by selling advertising time on TV and by renting out TV programmes.

Gameplay is rather complicated for a Pepys game.
From the predealt hand of cards (5) players try to find three cards with the same index number. In order to achieve this they can draw from the open or from the unexposed stock pile.
You have to have the appropriate time card before buying a programme, and to get this, you can open a bidding round if the exposed programme card is to your liking but you do not have the time card you want.
By the way you try to advertise for other players ad companies.
Round ends when a player has a complete hand, consisting of 3 programme cards and 2 ad cards. Certain rules apply for those, too.
Now players receive funds from the authority or from other players, depending which companies products they advertised.
Game ends after given rounds, i.e. at least 6 for 2, 3 or 6 players.

boardgame.name: Hop Off: USA Edition
boardgame.description:
Description from the Publisher's website @

http://www.borderlinegames.com/hopoff.html

It's geography hopscotch - hop on and you're off and learning about the geography of the United States!

Play with one or more teams!

For each player's turn, a team leader draws one state card from the deck. Standing on either the Pacific or the Atlantic Ocean side, the player has three chances to toss the bean bag onto that state.

When the player has succeeded in tossing the beanbag onto his target state, he hops from one ocean, across the map, naming aloud each state he hops on as he "travels" - that way everyone is learning their United States geography! When he reaches a state that borders his target state, he retrieves the beanbag and continues hopping off to the ocean on the other side.

The team wins when it has "traveled" to all 48 contiguous states!

Time your team for even more fun!

Play with the capitals only, or with both the states and the capitals for a real challenge!

"HEROES in Mythical Greece" is a greek CCG (Collectible Card Game) that takes place in Ancient Greece. The game is heavily based in the greek mythology trying to be as faithful to it as possible.

The players take control of a famous greek Hero and they play allies, locations, actions and equipment to assist him in his quests. The game can be played in two modes "Duels" and "Quests". In "Quests" players try to advance their Hero, by taking him from his early age and completing quests in order to take fame and have him rise to become a living legend. At the same time their opponents try to stop them by playing monsters that will prevent them from completing their quests. The first one to reach a certain level of fame wins.

Currently, only one set has come out, the first Rhapsody as it is being called, named Genesis. There are plans for more expansions in the following years.

Die Siedler von Hessen (The Settlers of Hesse) is the first in a new series of historical regional map expansions for the venerable Settlers of Catan line. The new line profiles famous regions of Germany during the Middle Ages, when Celts, Romans, and Germans intermingled.

Die Siedler von Hessen celebrates the state of Hesse, home to Wiesbaden and Frankfurt am Main. Like Die Siedler von Nürnberg and the other historical expansions, it features a fixed map board. The geographic features (resource hexes) and cities mirror the approximate location of their real-world counterparts. "Harbors" ring the playing field.

The rules of Hessen cleave closely to those of standard Catan, with a few departures to keep things interesting. Players may only build cities in the round intersections denoting actual cities. Because some of the cities are only one hexside apart, the spacing rule requiring two roads between settlements is not in effect. Having built a road to a hex with a settlement, one cannot build a road leaving it until one has build a settlement on the hex. Finally, to obtain the benefit of a harbor, it is only necessary to lay a road on the hexside shaded in red.

Die Siedler von Hessen is followed in six month intervals with new additions to the map line, each adding a new German region. Next in the lineup are Die Siedler von Rhein, Die Siedler von Pfalz (Palatinate), and Die Siedler von Saar.

Part of the Catan Series.

boardgame.name: Stop Thief
boardgame.description:
Two players compete in trying to collect all the cards in the deck. To play, all cards are dealt one by one to each player face down in a pile. The dealer goes first and flips over his top card from his pile onto the center of the table. The other player flips over his top card onto the played card. If the player places on top of the pile a card with a number (Officers), he captures the pile unless his opponent can recapture them. Recapture is achieved by the player flipping over an Officer card in the amount of turns of the previous displayed numbered card. For example, if the player placed a ‘Cop’ card which is numbered 3, then the opponent would have 3 turns to try and place on top of that card another numbered Officer card. If he cannot recapture, his opponent gets to take all the cards in the pile.

Stop Thief consists of 32 cards. There are 20 thief cards and 12 officer cards. The officer cards include 4 cards depicting each a detective, cop, and police chief.

boardgame.name: Armed Warfare
boardgame.description:
ARMED WARFARE covers all aspect of surface warfare during the WWII era.

Armor, infantry, mines, artillery - on and off board - aerial interdiction, amphibious landings, open and urban terrain. The size of the arena can be any size players desire, 2'x2' with a few men to 4'x8' with lots of men and/or tanks. Shooting ranges extend out to eight feet. The rules are based on - What you see is what you get. One on one. Info is provided for almost every vehicle and general type of small arms from 1936 to 1954. All scales can use the rules: micro to 1/35th. Large number of vehicles will use the main rules and the few specially for that scale. 15mm to 1/35 will probably be infantry combat with a few supporting vehicles. These will use the main rules, the few rules for the large figures and the matrix for receiving wounds. The matrix is designed so a man might be hit, wound and live to fight some more. The last part would be at a reduced ability. A man hit in the left arm can still shot a pistol with his right hand.

boardgame.name: Wild West
boardgame.description:
Game set in the American Wild West.

Object of the game is to win cards having green numbers on them, namely the outlaw or holdup cards.

Game consists of 15 cowboy cards, numbered 1-15, 15 outlaw cards with red numbers 1-15 and green 1-5, 11 holdup cards with green numbers 1-5 and 3 sheriff cards.

The holdup cards form a different stack, top card exposed.
Rest of cards are dealt out.
Players can decide to play either outlaw or cowboy/sheriff each round of play.

After every player has laid out a card, trick is taken by the player with the highest worth in either outlaw or cowboy suit. Sheriff cancels all played cards.
Game plays best with three, if only 2 play, a "dummy" has to be dealt out.
Gameplay also suits for partnership play.

As usual top card quality in graphics and material.

boardgame.name: Danger Game
Haettuspil
Hættuspil
boardgame.description:
In Hættuspil (or Danger Game) the player takes on the role of a young person and his or her object is to collect the 25 points needed to win. Collecting points is done by buying items according to each person's interests. The points can be lost as well, for example if the player gets a drug card.

The game was designed and published by the founders of CCP to finance the beginning of their EVE Online project.

According to the manual of the 2013 re-release, Danger Game was developed in collaboration with Iceland's Alcoholics Anonymous group to teach children the inherent dangers of drinking and drug use.

The game's original box art features a man, actor Jón Gnarr Kristinsson, dressed as a woman. Years later, Jón Gnarr (as he has legally changed his name to now) would become mayor of Iceland's capitol city Reykjavík. When developer CCP considered re-releasing Danger Game as part of an anniversary box set for EVE Online, it approached the former model and mayor to reprise his role as the damsel on the cover. Gnarr agreed and appears on the reissued game's art.

boardgame.name: Auditions
boardgame.description:
If the terms “Theater Sports” or “Whose Line Is It Anyway?” mean anything to you, you’ll recognize the spirit behind this Theatrical Styled party game.

Impersonations, Charades, Jokes, Songs, Improvisation and more.

From the early years of Decipher, Inc, Auditions at times resembles an elaborate version of Cranium, while at other times it seems like a party-event-in-a-box, reminiscent of a Murder Mystery Dinner Party, with Wayne Brady standing in for Sherlock Holmes.

From the box:
AUDITIONS, the game
"everybody wants to get into the act" tm
Now you can too.

See your friends in a whole new light - the spotlight - as Auditions turns your living room into center stage for the evening!
- See your button-down brother-in-law become the world's fattest ballerina!
- Hear your best friend as a TV evangelist begging for bucks! Hallelujah!
- Experience your next door neighbors playing the hapless victims of the "Mattress Tag Police"
- You had no idea your mom knew THAT joke, or that ELVIS LIVES... in your great aunt Bertha!
- Witness your boss become... almost lifelike! You'll laugh! You'll cry! You'll laugh 'til you cry!

If you get a charge out of a great impersonation, appreciate a good joke or a clever charade, you'll love Auditions! Off-the-wall scripts, goofy songs and more, combine for an evening you'll never forget! Play Auditions to get rave reviews! Your family and friends will be begging for an encore!

If you have any questions, feel free to send us an email (laden@gamers-hq.de), give us a call (+49 30 79706126) or visit our homepage (www.gamers-hq.de).
Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

8 Scenarios

Not a complete game by itself, this scenario pack requires ownership of modules from the ASL system to play.

boardgame.name: Angel Wars Board Game
boardgame.description:
The Angel Wars strategy board game is simple to learn. Yet, it has a depth of strategy that is fascinating to players of all levels. The game features the excellent art and intriguing characters from the amazing animated series, Angel Wars.

The game begins with the game tiles set up in checkerboard design. You control the 6 guardian angels. Your opponent controls the 6 demons (or the 6 messenger angels if your opponent prefers not to play the demons). Players take turns moving, following the rules of movement, until one player has successfully moved all of his/her pieces to the opposite sides of the board.

However, it’s not that simple. You can only move your piece on a tile of matching color. Players flip tiles to match their piece. You must find a way to clear a path for both your blue pieces and your orange pieces while trying to block your opponent’s pieces in the process.

Offering two styles of play, this game is sure to become a favorite among game players of all ages and skill levels.

boardgame.name: Lange Jan
Langer Lulatsch
boardgame.description:
Roll the diamant die (a transparent d8) to determine the goal-number (= die roll + 4). Then any player is dealt this number of cards from the shuffled deck, that contains the various body parts: feet, legs, torsos, shoulders, and heads in lots of length and combinations.

Your goal is to build a "Langer Lulatsch" (Beanpole) with the right length (the goal-number as number of cards) to get the most points in the round (goal-number +3). Everyone who finishes a correct Lulatsch within the same trun, gets the number of cards of his figure.

The problem is to decide when to add which cards to your figure, as you have only one action per round deciding wether to draw a new card while discarding an old one (either from the drawpile or one of the discardpiles) or "build" your figure. And for example not all feet go with all legs as some have trousers and other have not. Once built you can't change the features and you have to build from bottom to top.

There is another round until the first player gets 50 points.

boardgame.name: Monopoly: Puerto Rico
boardgame.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

A licensed Hasbro Monopoly variant set in Puerto Rico.

This Spanish company appeared in the mid 80s and published this and another title, Tutankhamon (see entry)

In the meanwhile, they have to hunt, fish, confront wild animals, fight another tribes and suffer natural disasters such as earthquakes or epidemies. Obtaining fire is essential to keep food.

The game contents were poorly presented, but it was funny to play and it would have been really good with some extra work on rules and graphic design.

boardgame.name: ibara no hime to yonnin no kishi
The Thorn Princess and the Four Knights
いばらの姫と４人の騎士
boardgame.description:
Translated from the backside:
In this game, the players become royal knights, and their goal is to reclaim the princess who has shut herself into the Thorn Castle.
However, the princess is a selfish one, and she doesn't want to leave the Castle.
In order to get her out of there, the knights must earn her trust by pleasing (resolving) the selfish wishes she constantly repeats.

The knights use their cards to move around the board looking for useful things, awaiting the chance to take the princess with them. But once they claim the princess (for example, by defeating the knight she currently is accompanied by), she starts ranting "I'm hungry", "I want to rest" and other silly requests.
The winner is the player who succeeds in earning the princess' trust by clearing three of these requests and escorting her outside the castle's walls.

A3 Game board

84 Action cards
20 Event cards
20 Rant cards
6 cardboard figures (1 for each knight, 1 princess, 1 event marker)

24 item chips
1 rule book

Designed by Seiji Kanai
Illustrations by Noboru Sugiura

One out of 30 pictures from art history is hidden under 12 wooden tiles and revealed part by part. After any "revelation" the players have to answer one of 14 questions from a questionnaire and talk about the part that can be seen plus answering the question. Each answer that sounds correct to the other players, gets a point (chip).

Since any player is allowed to answer each question only once, it gets harder in the successing game to reply properly.

After the picture is completely revealed, the answers are re-checked in the rulebook, and each correct answer gets more points.

More a game for funny talk and make it believable, than for real art education. But the details you can explore in the process of revealing the pictures and discuss the answers, are illuminative fun.

boardgame.name: Galaxy
boardgame.description:
Galaxy was first published as "game in the magazine" in the AHA-Zeitung #87/2, the zine of several joint Swiss Playing Clubs. In winter 1987, Editoy published it as a real game.

The huge board shows a universe with 6 planets, 36 space stations and about 50 meteorites. The planets are connected with thick planet routes, the space stations with thinner space station routes, and the meteorites with dotted meteorite routes. Movement is done with movement tickets, which are won by throwing a die.

Each planet is the home planet of a player's space ship, thus up to 6 people can play a game.

Object of the game is to visit all 6 space station of the own colour and return to the home planet first. This can be rather difficult, because 18 "magnetic fields" block the same number of routes. Besides moving his space ship during his turn, a player takes any magnetic field and places it on a new route.

boardgame.name: Club 3
boardgame.description:
Club 3 was first published as game in the magazine in "WIN" #45, the zine of the "Spielekreis Wien" in Austria. It was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" two months later.

The game is somehow a derivate of Poker - with less cards, less combinations, but more interactions between the players.

The card deck consists of only 24 cards; 4 suits of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6.

There are only 3 combinations with a little strange names:
- Wortklauberei (logomachy): 2 cards with numbers directly adjacent each other
- Redeschwall (flood of words): 2 cards with the same numbers
- Phasendreschen (to rant): 2 cards, 1 showing an "1", the other a "6"

Each round is played with 4 cards per player; there is no possibility to exchange any of them. The first player, who thinks he has a good hand, starts the game by playing 1 card and any number of chips on it. This bet can be attacked by any player. The attacker can choose, if he wants to attack alone or with the help of another player. That means, that the original better can be forced to play against 2 players! An important restriction is, that a maximum of 3 cards can be used on each side, which would form 1 or 2 combinations.

The game ends after a preassigned time and the player with the most chips is the winner.

boardgame.name: High Noon
boardgame.description:
High Noon was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #87/4.

The board consists of 12 spaces, where 12 subsequent races are carried out.

Each of the 4 players has 1 token and a set of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6. These cards are used to move the tokens. Every turn, all players play one of their cards simultaneously. Passing other tokens is possible at the cost of 2 movement points, but landing on occupied fields is forbidden; such a move would forfeit.

While the first race starts with all tokens off the board, the following 11 races leave all tokens where they have been at the end of the previous race. But the finishing line will be shifted by 7 fields.

Up to 12 points can be won per race and the winner is the player with the most points after all 12 races.

boardgame.name: Godzilla
boardgame.description:
Godzilla was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #88/1.

The game is played on a 10x10 board. One player plays with Gozilla, the other one plays with 6 people/tokens from Tokyo. Each of the 6 Tokyo tokens has a different colour and wears an imaginary weapon of the same colour.

Before the game begins, the Tokyo player places 40 houses, 10 monster-immune houses and his 6 tokens on the board. Gozilla waits outside the board.

The Gozilla player is dealt 6 cards showing the 6 colours of the weapons. He is immune against 4 of the 6 weapons and to document which ones, he secretly keeps 4 of the 6 cards.

During a turn, the Tokyo player must move 3 of his tokens by 1 space, the Gozilla player moves Gozilla by 2 spaces. Gozilla can destroy houses, but not Tokyo tokens or monster-immune houses.

The Tokyo player wins, if he can move one of his 2 tokens with a "sharp" weapon on the space where Gozilla is. Gozilla wins, if he can destroy 15 houses before he is killed.

boardgame.name: Burza Zimowa 1942
Deblokada Stalingradu 1942
boardgame.description:
Burza Zimowa 1942 (Winter Storm 1942) : the Germans hoped to relieve the 6th Army encircled in Stalingrad by breaking through the Russian lines. The operation was a failure since the Soviet HQ sent strong reinforcements to the area and stopped the German advance and thus the 6th Army was doomed.

The game uses rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions (Germans) or regiments (Russians), one hex represents 1500m, one turn represents 12 hours.

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

boardgame.name: Szczury Pustyni
boardgame.description:
Szczury Pustyni (Desert Rats) depicts several battles fought in Libya between 1940 and 1942. Counters and scenarios are for Operation Compass (British victory over the Italians), Rommel's first offensive (pushing the British back to Egypt), Operation Battleaxe (first and failed attempt by the Allies to relieve Tobruk), Operation Crusader (successful Allied attempt to relieve Tobruk) and Battle of Gazala (Rommel's second thrust that reached Egypt).

The game uses simplified rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed to simulate medium battles of World War II with some additional rules too, dealing with specific aspects of desert warfare. Counters represent battalions, one hex represents 3000m, one turn represents one day.

boardgame.name: Bagration 1944
boardgame.description:
A wargame about the final phase of Russian offensive in summer 1944. After the success of operation Bagration and destruction of German Army Group Centre, the Soviets advanced quickly towards the Vistula river and Warsaw. Already exhausted from the earlier fights and 500km advance the Russians encountered strong German forces pulled from the Italian front just when they were about to cross Vistula and capture Warsaw. At the same time the Warsaw Uprising began, complicating the German situation.

The game uses the "Wielkie Bitwy II Wojny 1939-45" or "WB95" (Great Battles of World war II 1939-1945) rules designed to simulate large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents 2500m, one turn represents one day.

boardgame.name: Végvári Viadalok
boardgame.description:
Description from the gamebox:

Border Castle Battles

A strategic-historical game for children above 10. This is a stop-gap game in the sense that is provides exciting passtime activity for children above ten and even adults. The point is that the game enables you to re-play four campaigns of the 16th century /they took place actually/ with a relatively high degree of faithfulness to reality. This game is not the usual simple one you play with dice, it requires brains, tactics and good strategic ideas. If there are two players, one is the commander-in-chief of the Turkish army the other one is that of the Hungarian one. They take steps on the battlefield /the table/ which is authentic both historically and geographically.
While stepping forward - in line with their strategic ideas - they fight each other, protect or storm fortresses. In case of more players the countries may be divided among them, e.g. the players can be commanders of a Northern Hungarian castle or that of a Transdanubian fortress respectively...()
We sincerely hope that this short piece of information arouse your interest in this type of game outstanding also in its design, and being the first of its kind - since historical strategic games are just about to be spread in Hungary...()

boardgame.name: Fem myror är fler än fyra elefanter: Lär om siffror
boardgame.description:
A sister game of `Fem myror är fler än fyra elefanter: Lär om bokstäver´, this is a children´s game about numbers. There are seven different ways to play, representing seven difficulty levels.

Players each have their own board. A number of tiles are placed face-down on the table, a la Memory. Players roll the die to see how many tiles (1, 2 or 3) they may turn face-up. Any tiles that match the player´s board are placed on the board.

In the seven variants, players are required to match numbers with numbers (2 - 2, easy), animals with numbers (two lions - 2, slightly more advanced), and so on.

The winner is the first player to fill his/her board.

Themed on a very popular Swedish TV show for kids.

boardgame.name: Cradle of Renaissance
Die Wiege der Renaissance
boardgame.description:
From the publisher (site: http://www.ddd-verlag.de ).

An innovative cardgame from Hanno and Wilfried Kuhn situated in Florenz - the cradle of the Renaissance. Artists such as Botticelli, Michelangelo and da Vinci worked in this city, the preacher Savonarola established a God state and Machiavelli wrote his works on the theory of power. Here the Medici prevailed and the city saw the birth of important discoverers such as Vespucci.

As the head of an influential European aristocracy you will try to lead your family to a cultural and power-political top. In the face of the historical events of this time you promote cultural achievements such as architecture and religion, financing, the sciences and naturally also the voyages of discovery. Surround yourself with the powerful ones of this time and use all your diplomacy skills to achieve a crucial advantage against your competitors. Only the player with the most influence stones will win the game ...

Box content:
- 36 historical events
- 40 culture cards
- 27 person cards
- 5 summary cards
- 28 influence stones (7 in each of the colors yellow, red, black and white)
- 4 genius figures (1 in each of the colors yellow, red, black and white)
- 1 rules book

boardgame.name: About Time
About Time: Das Zeit-Spiel
boardgame.description:
Teams compete to guess closest to the year of a historic event, which is read out from a Question Card. Winning teams collect tokens and roll the dice to move around the board in a race to the Center.

The game includes a board, eight different characters to represent the teams playing, a sandglass timer, two dice, a scoresheet, six pencils, a novel magnetic category selection unit, question/answer cards, timecards, rules, and a mini-reference sheet.

The game is played in rounds, the first of which is similar to a round of trivial pursuit. The second round introduces timecards, which tweaks gameplay by giving teams various powers, such as stealing points. The game sequence also changes to shake things up a bit.

Very much like an exciting Trivial Pursuit, adding various new mechanics.

Released at Spiel 2007.

boardgame.description:
Disambiguation: This game is for the Golden Compass movie, the game for the book is located over here.




Players are part of Philip Pullman’s creation, as portrayed in the motion picture: a world very much like our own, but existing in a parallel universe. The game features graphics and pictures taken from the movie. Players alternate in leading Lyra in her journey to rescue her friends, as she escapes from the Magisterium's clutches. As each turn unfolds, players collect items and clues, and help Lyra to understand the Alethiometer - the truth-measuring Golden Compass. During a turn a player uses the Alethiometer spindle: the spinning action reveals the two actions the player is allowed to choose from. A typical move involves playing or drawing Lyra cards, played in sets to collect Item tiles from the board (representing Lyra and Pan's actions and investigations) or placing Symbol tokens that will later let a player draw valuable Truth tokens (representing the interpretation of the Alethiometer). Character cards, showing the main heroes and villains of the story, can be used by players to alter the gameplay by applying their special abilities. The winner is the player that scores the most points by the end of the game.

boardgame.description:
In Cockroach Salad players create a common salad packed with lettuce, peppers, tomatoes and cauliflower – but they won't always be saying which ingredient they're adding to the bowl!

The 128 cards – 120 vegetable cards in the four types and eight "taboo" vegetable cards, two of each type that bear cockroaches – are shuffled and divided among the players. On a turn, a player plays the top card from his deck onto the central pile of cards, naming the vegetable as he plays it, e.g., "Pepper!" – except in the following situations:

• If his vegetable matches the previously played vegetable, the player must lie.
• If his vegetable matches the claim made by the previous player (perhaps because that player lied), then the player must lie.
• If he plays a taboo card, he shouts "Cockroach!" and the next player starts a new pile next to the first one so that the taboo card remains visible.
• If his vegetable matches a visible taboo card, he must lie.

Make a mistake or stumble or hesitate too long, and a player must pick up all cards played to that point in the game. The first player to run out of cards wins!

Can be combined with Kakerlakensuppe.

boardgame.name: De Matrica Bellae
boardgame.description:
De Matrica Bellae is a set of matrix game rules for tabletop wargames by Graham D. Evans and was published as the Society of Ancients incentive game for 2005. The matrix style of play often produces an anarchic type of game and also needs an umpire, but can produce an entertaining game that is good fun and can provide a lot of value to the wargamer. DMB also includes a bonus matrix game campaign, "Londinium's Burning" - a matrix version of the Iceni revolt led by Boudicca.

(from the SOA website)

Matrix games use structured arguments rather than mathematics to determine the success or failure of actions within the game.

boardgame.name: Super Tock 4
Le Tock
Tock
boardgame.description:
Tock is a board game, similar to Pachisi, in which players race their four tokens around the game board from start to finish—the objective being to be the first to take all of one's tokens "home". Instead of rolling the dice to the determined movement, players are dealt cards to use for movement.

Players take turns playing cards, with the value of the card determining how far they may move a pawn. Certain cards have special possibilities (a King or an Ace may be played to get a new pawn into play, while a four moves you back instead of forward).

If more than two players a playing, they can play in teams. When you have brought all your own pawns to your safety zone, you must move your partner's pawns.

boardgame.name: ABOYNE
boardgame.description:
Aboyne is a simple, fast-paced, print and play abstract game.

On their turn, a player must move one stone of their own color that is not adjacent to any enemy stone. A stone may (i) move to an adjacent empty cell or (ii) jump over a friendly stone, or a line of friendly stones, landing on the cell immediately beyond. If that cell is occupied by an enemy stone, that stone is captured. A stone cannot move into the opponent's goal cell. The winner is the player who moves a stone into their own goal cell (at the opposite end of the board) or stalemates the opponent.



The Term Aboyne

The term Aboyne is taken from a humorous dictionary The deeper meaning of Liff. by Douglas Adams and John Lloyd. In there Aboyne is defined as beating an expert at a game of skill by playing so appallingly that none of his clever tactics or strategies are of any use to him.

Furthermore there exists a village in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, named Aboyne (Scots: Abyne, Scottish Gaelic: Abèidh).

boardgame.name: The Great Migration
The Great Migration
boardgame.description:
During the nineteenth century, settlers expanded rapidly across North America, from the eastern seaboard all the way to the west coast. Players' pieces represent the wagons of a bold family just arrived from the Old World and working to reach the west coast. Performance is based not on how well any one wagon does, but on how well players manage all of their wagons.

The game is played as a trick-taking game. The goal of the game is to advance wagons as quickly as possible. Every trick scores movement points. These points propel wagons across the board.

Every hand also features a hand evaluation step. Bidding a hand correctly scores extra movement points. Missing a bid scores nothing.

Blocking is also an important element of the game. By placing wagons on the game board’s prime paths, players can force each other to either go around or give up some of their precious points to push opponents forward and out of the way.

This game has been self published (at prototype quality) in an edition not to exceed 200 copies.

boardgame.name: Quest for the Princess
boardgame.description:
from the website http://www.elveneargames.nl

Five of the most noble knights in the country, all want to marry the princess. There is one problem, though. The princess has been kidnapped by a dangerous dragon Fortunately, something good comes out of this situation too. This is the ultimate chance for the courageous warriors to make a good impression on the princess. That is why they go to battle to save the princess. Because only one of them can marry the lady, the knights do everything whithin their power to make life miserable for one another. This whole spectacle is watched by a very critical royal family. The knights really work their heads off to win the sympathy of the family. They will most certainly put in a good word for them with the princess.

Goal of the game:
The players are knights. The player who makes the biggest impression on the princess, can marry her and wins the game. Players collect points by fighting other knights (fighting), impressing family members of the princess with their spectacular horse riding shows (showing), riding faster that their opponents (trotting), winning a tournament and ofcourse by saving the princess.

The player characters in the game:
Sir Thanks-a-lot, Sir Chop-a-lot, Sir Robin Rudes prince of Dudes, Sir William Wimpy and the Dirty Duke of Dastardshire

This game is released at Essen 2007.

boardgame.name: Spinjas
boardgame.description: Spinjas is a ratcheted spinning top game created by Parker Brothers in the late 1980s. The game set was sold as a Battle Stadium plastic arena with two Power Winder launchers and two Spinja characters enclosed within the clam-shell designed arena. More characters, launchers, and an oversized playing arena were also made available separately. The objective of the game is to load your chosen character into the ratcheting launcher and each player would launch their top into the arena at the same time. The tops would ricochet off of each other until only one remained spinning or within the arena and that player was declared the winner.The tops are not customizable and are not associated with any other licensed properties.

boardgame.name: Mind Twist
boardgame.description: Mind Twist is a 2-player game that has players racing to be the first to get to the top of a 3-D Board. On your turn, secretly select a number between 1 and 3. If your opponent doesn't challenge you, you reveal your secret number and move your piece closer to victory and then it's your opponent's turn. If your opponent challenges you, he or she tries to guess your secret number. If they get it right, you lose your turn and they now pick a number. If they get it wrong, you reveal your secret number and move that many spaces and take another turn.

boardgame.name: Snap-Jacks
boardgame.description:
The board consists of a 4x4 square grid of scoring positions with a point value of either 5, 10, or 15. Each scoring position contains a 5x5 grid of holes. So the overall interior grid of holes is 20x20. Around the edges of the board are 23 additional single holes which are scattered sparsely, with values from 25 to 75.

Each player gets a seesaw-like device with a hole in one end for placing his or her jacks. Players then 'snap' the other end of the device to fling the jack into the air and (one hopes) into a hole on the board. Jacks that do land in holes on the board score based on where they land.

If you have any questions, feel free to send us an email (laden@gamers-hq.de), give us a call (+49 30 79706126) or visit our homepage (www.gamers-hq.de).
Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

boardgame.name: Solar Bases
boardgame.description:
This game uses a space exploration theme to teach players about number bases (binary, octal, decimal, etc.). Each player starts play with a "matrix card," a supply of plastic chips and a "flight sheet" for scoring. Gameplay consists of five flights, each containing two phases: "Blast Off" and "Establishing a Flight Path." After five flights have been completed, the player with the highest total score is declared the winner.

During the "Blast Off" phase, the player voted mission commander draws and announces cards from a special deck of playing cards containing the standard four suits but only the numbers 1 through 9 (Ace is replaced by 1, and no face cards are included). Players place chips on their matrix cards, Bingo-style, until every player has at least one complete row or column of chips. At this point, players choose from among the 3- and 4-digit numbers filled in on their cards to establish "flight numbers," which are written on their sheets.

In the "Establishing a Flight Path" phase, players are dealt cards from a second deck of "base cards." Some of these cards contain game-balancing bonuses and penalties which apply only when drawn by players holding specially-marked matrix cards. The remaining base cards list a planet of the solar system, the number base that the planet represents in the game, and a list of digits which are valid in the planet's base. For example, Mercury represents binary (base 2), so only digits 0 and 1 are allowed. The player replaces all illegal digits in his or her flight number with zeroes, then converts the resulting number to decimal using a special base conversion wheel included with the game (except for landings on Pluto, which already represents base 10 and requires no conversion). The final result is added to his or her score.

The game includes two sets of rules -- "Brief Instructions" which get players started in just two pages, and a 10-page "Guide Book" which includes more detailed instructions, game variations and mathematical background information. The game was filed as U.S. Patent 3,618,952.
